newsitem.title: UK: RUGBY UNION-NO EARLY SOLUTION TO ENGLISH RUGBY CRISIS.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-NO EARLY SOLUTION TO ENGLISH RUGBY CRISIS.

text.p: The turmoil in English rugby was no closer to a solution on Wednesday after a meeting between the England players and the organisation representing the clubs who want to split from the Rugby Football Union (RFU).

After boycotting a scheduled national training session, the 43-strong squad assembled at a Heathrow hotel to hear a presentation from the English Professional Rugby Union Clubs (EPRUC) who wish to take control of the domestic game.
EPRUC issued a brief statement after the meeting, which said the England squad had agreed "in principle with EPRUC'S vision for the future".
EPRUC chairman Donald Kerr refused to comment further on the statement and said only: "If you want to read into it that the England players agree with the breakaway, then fine."
The England management and coach Jack Rowell turned up as scheduled for the training session even though there were no players to work with.
RFU secretary Tony Hallett is expected to state the union's position on Thursday as they seek to regain control of a sport which has been transformed by the introduction of professionalism.
Among those also present at the meeting was Newcastle chairman Sir John Hall who had interrupted his holiday in Spain to be part of the negotiating team.
He said he was "delighted" with developments and added: "It is very satisfying that they have kept away from training. We are all sticking together for the good of the game."
